text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonyous questions. 

Career stage: entry (0-1 years of experience)

"Hello. I am struggling with writing plagiarism-free content. Recently I got fired from the company where I have been working as a content writer. And the reason that I got fired is that I have used scam tools for plagiarism detection and it doesn't detect the plagiarized piece of content. Any advice on how to improve your writing in case you don't have an appropriate budget for using premium tools)"

What a great story! The ability to know when we need to pull back in our careers and when we're ready to take on more stress / responsibility is a real asset. Claim that as part of your story. Anyone worth their salt should be excited to add this experience to their team.

I do not see any good reason why you should need to "work your way back up" again. You should be extremely confident going after roles similar to or even more ambitious than your previous role.

There are absolutely companies that will punish any resume gap. Ignore them.

idk about broader trends -- I would probably avoid early-stage startups (Series A or B) which are often finding their way and can be overall chaotic as a result. Otherwise, I don't see why a job in tech wouldn't fit what you're after.

Good luck!

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text:

text: Cite everything. Even if you're paraphrasing, link back to the original source.  You can try Grammarly's free plagiarism checker. <https://www.grammarly.com/plagiarism-checker>

attachments.title: Plagiarism Checker by Grammarly
attachments.text: Instant plagiarism check for essays and documents. Detect plagiarism, fix grammar errors, and improve your vocabulary in seconds.

elements.text: Cite everything. Even if you're paraphrasing, link back to the original source.  You can try Grammarly's free plagiarism checker.

text: Thanks so much for your thoughts and encouragement, <@UJG12DM1V>! If I’m being real real being a new mom has made me confident in ways I’ve never been before…and also has tested my insecurities I thought I left behind a while ago, especially in my professional life. It’s good to hear other people’s perspectives.

elements.text: Thanks so much for your thoughts and encouragement,

! If I’m being real real being a new mom has made me confident in ways I’ve never been before…and also has tested my insecurities I thought I left behind a while ago, especially in my professional life. It’s good to hear other people’s perspectives.

text: That's awesome! The one thing I always love about working with parents is they are incredibly good at prioritization. You all have to be! There just isn't time to waste on stupid things and there is a strong sense for what constitutes and emergency -- like a serious injury or accident is an emergency, anything in marketing is hands down not an emergency. I love that.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
I'm a little confused here... isn't the user of the plagiarism tool the client, not the writer? As in, the writer should know if they're plagiarizing and not need a tool to tell them that.

<@U01AU94TABA>, I'm assuming you're reading this as the OP copy-pasted some other article's phrasing into their piece and were somehow caught not citing by the client's more expensive tool?

elements.text: I'm a little confused here... isn't the user of the plagiarism tool the client, not the writer? As in, the writer should know if they're plagiarizing and not need a tool to tell them that.
, I'm assuming you're reading this as the OP copy-pasted some other article's phrasing into their piece and were somehow caught not citing by the client's more expensive tool?

text: Or there's the case where you coincidentally write the exact same phrase as elsewhere... but I feel like even with the generic approaches inside content mills, the odds are pretty low. Maybe that's not the case? Hm.

text: I second all that <@UJG12DM1V> says, and add that consulting or agency roles also tend to be fast-paced and sometimes do not offer as much balance for parents. I know some caregivers that thrive in those roles, but as a parent, I found it more challenging.

elements.text: I second all that

says, and add that consulting or agency roles also tend to be fast-paced and sometimes do not offer as much balance for parents. I know some caregivers that thrive in those roles, but as a parent, I found it more challenging.

text: Thanks for your thoughts, <@U015B88C4CA>! I’m noticing the same about consulting and agencies. I really loved working for a marketing agency, so  maybe I can return again, one day. :slightly_smiling_face: But it had its cons even before I became a mom. :joy:

text: <@U012UL77GUT> Look for companies with a “family-friendly” culture. You can look for this on the about us pages, and ask very specific questions about work/life balance in the interview. Better yet, I’m a fan of talking to current employees for a better take on things. They can tell you if the work/life balance aspect exists or not. There are lists and awards that rank companies in different categories...such as best workplaces for single parents, families, women. Two companies that fit this ideal are UKG (Ultimate Kronos Group) and Sailpoint Technologies in Austin, Texas.  Good luck!

Two companies that fit this ideal are UKG (Ultimate Kronos Group) and Sailpoint Technologies in Austin, Texas.  Good luck!

text: Also - I’ve found this site by Wildbit to be a great baseline as to what a good company could look like: <https://peoplefirstjobs.com/|https://peoplefirstjobs.com/>

attachments.title: People-First Jobs
attachments.text: People-First Jobs is a curated list of companies who take a healthy approach to work and are looking for motivated people like you.

elements.text: Also - I’ve found this site by Wildbit to be a great baseline as to what a good company could look like:
https://peoplefirstjobs.com/

text:
Having been in this situation before, when there wasn't any clarity from the business on what was most important, I took two approaches:
1. Building and working through a prioritization framework that looked at all the possible things we could do as a team, and then scoring them based on impact to business, impact to customers, difficulty level, and confidence in their success. This helped us focus on the things that were going to have the biggest impact rather than the things that people were shouting the loudest about. We then went back to the rest of the marketing team to make sure everyone agreed with our scores. We ended up doing this once a quarter. GAME CHANGER. 
2. Running regular retros with my own team to see what was getting in their way, and what the biggest painpoints were. Often it wasn't what I was focused on. I then made sure I was working on problems that would benefit the health and success of my team (like educating stakeholders on how to fill out briefs), as well as problems that were going to benefit the business.

This helped us focus on the things that were going to have the biggest impact rather than the things that people were shouting the loudest about. We then went back to the rest of the marketing team to make sure everyone agreed with our scores. We ended up doing this once a quarter. GAME CHANGER.

Running regular retros with my own team to see what was getting in their way, and what the biggest painpoints were. Often it wasn't what I was focused on. I then made sure I was working on problems that would benefit the health and success of my team (like educating stakeholders on how to fill out briefs), as well as problems that were going to benefit the business.

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonyous questions. 

Career stage: senior (8+ years)

"Without diving into the context of my career path, I'd love to hear recommendations for addressing a lack of relevant samples for a particular job posting/industry. Do I wait to build up some relevant samples and then apply? Or do I have a shot if I apply with generic samples to, at the very least, demonstrate my grasp/style of writing while being open about my lack of specific experience (and also exuding a hearty, humble eagerness to learn and adapt if given the opportunity)? Thank you!"
Can't hurt to apply. Some job descriptions may though explicitly ask for expertise in a specific industry in which case if you're senior level I would  emphasize results you've achieved.

elements.text: Can't hurt to apply. Some job descriptions may though explicitly ask for expertise in a specific industry in which case if you're senior level I would  emphasize results you've achieved.

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonyous questions. 

Career stage: senior (8+ years)

"I'm making the transition from being an individual (expert) contributor to leading a large-ish team (5+ people). What's your best advice on how to succeed with this switch?"

Adding as a prefix to what Phillip said, you need to demonstrate your expertise through content assets. Now clients want something published in your name but to get published samples you need clients. The best way to get out of the cycle is MEDIUM. Demonstrate your expertise there. Or even LinkedIn articles. Use social proof strongly because when you are new in the niche, you will get a lot of "so what? prove it!" questions.
